column1: The Princess and the Pea;"There was once a prince who wanted to marry a princess. But she must be a real princess

column8: for he wished so much to marry a real princess. One evening a terrible storm came on. It thundered and lightened

column13: it ran in at the tips of her shoes and out at the heels; yet she insisted she was a real princess. Very well
column14: thought the old queen;  that we shall presently see.  She said nothing but went into the bedchamber and took off all the bedding
column15: then laid a pea on the sacking of the bedstead. Having done this
column16: she took twenty mattresses and laid them upon the pea and placed twenty eider-down beds on top of the mattresses. The princess lay upon this bed all the night. In the morning she was asked how she had slept. Oh
column17: most miserably!  she said.  I scarcely closed my eyes the whole night through. I cannot think what there could have been in the bed. I lay upon something so hard that I am quite black and blue all over. It is dreadful!  It was now quite evident that she was a real princess

column19: for he knew that in her he had found a true princess. And the pea was preserved in the cabinet of curiosities
column20: where it is still to be seen unless some one has stolen it. And this

column1: to the thatch at the back he’d easily get the cow up.
But still he couldn’t leave the churn
column2: for there was his little babe

column1: crawling about on the floor
column2: and 'if I leave it

column1: is sure to upset it.' So he took the churn on his back
column2: and went out

column1: with it; but then he thought he’d better first water the cow before he
turned her out on the thatch; so he took up a bucket to draw water out
of the well; but
column2: as he stooped down at the well’s brink

column1: ran out of the churn over his shoulders
column2: and so down into the well.

column1: Now it was near dinner-time
column2: and he hadn’t even got the butter yet; so

column1: he thought he’d best boil the porridge
column2: and filled the pot with water

column1: and hung it over the fire. When he had done that
column2: he thought the cow

column1: might perhaps fall off the thatch and break her legs or her neck. So he
got up on the house to tie her up. One end of the rope he made fast to
the cow’s neck
column2: and the other he slipped down the chimney and tied round

column1: his own thigh; and he had to make haste
column2: for the water now began to boil

column1: in the pot
column2: and he had still to grind the oatmeal.

column1: So he began to grind away; but while he was hard at it
column2: down fell the

column1: cow off the housetop after all
column2: and as she fell she dragged the man up

column1: the chimney
column2: by the rope. There he stuck fast; and as for the cow

column1: hung half-way down the wall
column2: swinging between heaven and earth

column1: could neither get down nor up.
And now the wife had waited seven lengths and seven breadths for her
husband to come and call them home to dinner; but never a call they had.
At last she thought she’d waited long enough
column2: and went home. But when

column1: she got there and saw the cow hanging in such an ugly place
column2: she ran up

column1: and cut the rope in two with her scythe. But as she did this
column2: down came

column1: her husband out of the chimney; and so when his old lady came inside the
kitchen
column2: there she found him standing on his head in the porridge-pot."
